repnme.cdata!:
Urban water sector reform in Senegal :
            innovative contract design to expand services to the poor

abstracts.cdata!:
In the 1990s, Senegal undertook major
            reforms of its urban water supply and sanitation (WSS)
            sector. The World Bank, which has been providing support to
            the Senegalese water sector for many years, assisted this
            reform through an International Development Association
            (IDA) credit. The water sector project resulted in
            significantly better services and financial health for the
            sector. Approximately one million extra people got water
            supply services. Social connections, changed billing
            practices, and more stand posts ensured the poor benefited
            from service expansion. Existing customers got more water of
            better quality. In addition, the utility is better run, with
            lower water losses and higher bill recovery. Keys to success
            were strong leadership and political will combined with an
            innovative institutional structure.

docna.cdata!:
Urban water sector reform in Senegal :
            innovative contract design to expand services to the poor

            SUPPLY PROJECT,TF036937-SENEGAL - CAPACITY BUILDING FOR ENVIRONMENT,TF036955-SENEGAL - LONG TERM WATER SECTOR,TF037645-SENEGAL - LONG TERM WATER SECTOR,TF037699-SENEGAL - LONG TERM WATER SECTOR,TF037700-SENEGAL - LONG TERM WATER SECTOR,TF054215-JSDF-SENEGAL: PUBLIC-PRIVATE
            PARTNERSHIP FOR HAND WASHING WITH SOAP (PP

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Water Sector Project
            convey a highly satisfactory project outcome, highly likely
            sustainability, with high institutional development impact,
            supported by highly satisfactory Bank and Borrower
            performances.  The lessons learned include: (1) The presence
            in the field of the task manager and the continuity of the
            Bank's preparation and supervision teams have been a
            critical factor for the success of the project; (2) A small
            Project Coordination Unit (only three professional staff)
            with a strong leadership is able to coordinate various
            executing agencies and implement two major complex projects
            simultaneously; (3) Rather than focusing on the
            institutional aspects of regulation, with the creation of
            autonomous regulatory agencies (often multi-sectoral), which
            have generated more problems than solutions, it might be
            more efficient to provide the Government with regulatory
            instruments (the financial model) to determine consumer
            tariffs and sector investments and to rely on the contract
            to regulate the private operator; (4) A good PSP option must
            contain properly designed performance incentives for the
            private sector as well as specific incentives to serve the
            poor and that regulation by contract can be successful if
            properly designed; and (5) The use of a financial model at
            the very early stage--to assess the level of mixed
            public/private investment that would be consistent with the
            financial equilibrium of the sector and with socially
            acceptable tariffs increases--was a powerful tool in guiding
            the sector to financial health and sustainability.
